Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: This morning, I woke up to the sound of my wife bustling around the kitchen, her voice echoing down the hall, “We need to vacuum, dust, and set the table before your cousins arrive!” I promised her I’d help, knowing how much she wanted everything perfect for our guests. But today was also election day, and I’d already planned to vote early. She gave me a list of chores to finish before noon, her eyes full of expectation. At the polling station, I joined the line, glancing at my watch, thinking of the unwashed dishes and the cluttered living room. Suddenly, an official called out, “If your last name starts with A–M, please move to the new line.” My last name fit, but the new line was longer and slower. The official’s tone left no room for argument. I hesitated, torn between following the rules as a responsible voter and hurrying home to help my wife. My mind raced, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time.
